Award.AwardTitle: Southeastern Lie Theory Workshop Series; Algebraic and Combinatorial Representation Theory (2015: NCSU); Algebraic Groups, Quantum Groups and Geometry (2016: UVA)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Southeastern Lie Theory Workshops will be held October 9-11, 2015 at North Carolina State University and May 23-26, 2016 at the University of Virginia. These workshops are part of the annual Southeastern Lie Theory Workshop Series held at universities in the southeastern region of USA since 2009. The workshop series website is http://pi.math.virginia.edu/lieworkshops/. The aim of the workshop series is to bring together senior and junior researchers, as well as graduate students, in order to build cohesive research groups in various aspects of Lie theory; to stimulate and enhance research collaborations in Lie theory; and to infuse a strong tradition of research and education in the region. Each workshop is centered on a research theme and will feature one or two main speakers, giving two to three expository talks that will be accessible to graduate students and postdocs in the workshop's theme area. In addition, there will be four to six invited talks by other researchers and contributed talks by junior researchers and advanced graduate students. Considerable time will be devoted to informal discussions among participants in small groups to work on specific research problems led by invited team leaders chosen from among the participants.

Algebraic, combinatorial and geometric Lie theory is a major area of mathematical research with important applications to many different areas of mathematics, physics, and computer science. Research in representation theory includes the study of quantized enveloping algebras, quantum function algebras, Kac-Moody Lie algebras, Hecke algebras, canonical bases and crystal bases, vertex operator algebras, Hall algebras, A-infinity algebras, quivers, cluster algebras, Hopf algebras, and Khovanov-Lauda-Rouquier algebras. The research theme for the workshop at NCSU in 2015 will be "Algebraic and Combinatorial Representation Theory" and the research theme for the workshop at UVA in 2016 will be "Algebraic Groups, Quantum Groups and Geometry."

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lie theory is a major area of modern mathematics. It has important connections with many areas ofmathematics, including topology, geometry, combinatorics, finite and infinite group theory, etc. It also has important applications to physics, computer science, engineering, etc.  In 2009, the PIs established a consortium called the ``Southeastern Lie Theory Network" to enhance regional research collaboration and provide a stronger educational environment for graduate students and junior researchers in the southeastern United States. The idea was to organize a series of annual workshops at various universities in the southeastern region. This report focuses on the two most recent workshops, held at North Carolina State University (NCSU) in 2015,and the University of Virginia (UVA) in 2016.

The workshop at North Carolina State University held during October 9 - 11, 2015 was entitled ``Algebraic and Combinatorial Representation Theory". At this workshop Professor Anne Schilling from University of California at Davis gave a minicourse on a reformulation of Kashiwara crystals called ``Stembridge crystals". In a series of three one hour long lectures, she surveyed the recent developments and mentioned some open problems. In addition, there were six invited talks by Daniel Orr (Virginia Tech), Toshiki Nakashima (Sophia University, Japan), Masato Okado (Osaka City University, Japan), Ben Webster (UVA), Jerzy Weyman (U. Connecticut), Peter Tingley (Loyola). Besides the invited talks, there were 19 contributed talks and a two hour AIM style discussion session led by Professor Kyu-Hwan Lee (U. Connecticut). At this workshop there were 90 registered participants including 25 women and 46 graduate students.

The University of Virginia workshop held during May 24 - 27, 2016 concentrated on ``Algebraic Groups, Quantum Groups and Geometry". There were two minicourses given by Pramod Achar (LSU) and Geordie Williamson (MPI/Sydney) on geometric and modular representation theory. While they presented the state of art in the area, their lectures were quite accessible to the general audience.  The minicourses were followed by  two hour AIM style discussion sessions led by Laura Rider (MIT/UGA). In addition there were 12 invited talks by  Huanchen Bao (U. Maryland),  Jonathan Brundan (U. Oregon),  Jon Carlson (UGA),  Christopher Drupieski (DePaul),  Jie Du (U. New South Wales),  Eric Friedlander (U. Southern California),  Stefan Kolb (Newcastle, UK),  George Lusztig (MIT),  Jennifer Morse (Drexel),  Daniel Nakano (UGA), Peng Shan (Paris-Sud), Jian-pan Wang (East China Normal University). Besides the invited talks, there were 15 contributed talks. At this workshop there were 137 registered  participants including 25 women and 71 graduate students.

Scientific Merit: 

The two workshops were focused on current ``hot" topics in Lie theory.  The talks were all of a high mathematical level, but were for the most part also expository, aimed at the graduate students and postdocs in the audience. In both meetings, considerable effort was made to allow ample discussion among the participants.  

Broader Impact:                                                       

The Southeastern Lie Theory Workshop Series has stimulated and enhanced research collaboration in Lie theory in the southeastern region of the US. The activities help foster a strong regional tradition of research and education, helping mathematics departments attract more minorities and underrepresented groups to the mathematical sciences. The format of the workshops provides valuable opportunity for graduate students and junior researchers to interact with each other and with senior faculty.
